title: Letatlin
transcript:
MATT WITKOVSKY: Soviet sculptor Vladimir Tatlin thought up his Letatlin as a flying machine for the common citizen. His “personal plane” had a basket where a pilot stretched out lengthwise, hands on the wing controls. Connected to the basket were two wing struts, like the one seen here, that spanned nearly 33 feet. The Letatlin gave shape to the soaring aspirations of Russia’s October Revolution.

MARK STEINBERG: If there’s one word that everybody thought the revolution was about, that’s freedom, especially among ordinary people, especially among peasants and workers. And it often looks like what we know as freedom—civil rights and the like. But in the context of the almost romantic, festive, utopian spirit, freedom takes on all sorts of other categories.

MATT WITKOVSKY: Liberation was a common goal of many otherwise varied and diverse experiments in art.

MARK STEINBERG: One of the great experiments of the time was an orchestra with no conductor because “who needs leadership?” Clothing. Who needs clothing? It’s just because we’re so ashamed of our bodies. We should go around naked in public, another big movement in the 1920s, actually. New visions of family, new visions of sexual relations, ideas about the city of the future, ideas about a culture that looks like nothing ever seen before. So there’s this constant sense just like Tatlin and his little beautiful structure you can do the impossible and elevate above the ordinary.
